chapter: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 1: A child has congenital cataract involving the visual axis, which was detected at birth. When 
should the child be operated up on?

options.c: At 1 year of age, when the globe attains normal size
options.d: At 4 years, when ocular and orbital growth is complete

questions.explanation:
The child should be operated at 4-6 weeks of age. 288 
Sold by @itachibot When a child has unilateral or bilateral cataract impairing vision (involving the visual axis), the 
cataract surgery must be performed before 2-4 months of age. This is because 2-4 months is the 
critical period for visual maturation and development of the fixation reflex in children. A 
unilateral cataract is more dangerous than a bilateral cataract because the risk of amblyopia is 
greater. Under-correction of intraocular lens (IOL) power is needed in children. In children < 2 years of age: • In unilateral cases, primary implantation is indicated as soon as the patient is fit for anesthesia, 
ideally between 2 and 3 months of age. The power is undercorrected by 20%. • The earlier the surgery is done, the better the chance that deep amblyopia can be overcome. • After the cataract has been aspirated, an elective posterior capsulectomy–anterior vitrectomy is 
performed. The posterior chamber IOL is inserted through a scleral tunnel, which is prepared in 
advance. • Sulcus implantation is indicated in neonates and infants less than 1 year of age. In children between 2 and 8 years of age: • An IOL is implanted but power is undercorrected by 10%. • An in-the-bag IOL is chosen for children above 1 year of age because they are less likely to need 
an IOL exchange. Beyond 8 years, IOL power is the same as the calculated value.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 2: In which of the following cataract surgeries is a self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision 
used?
questions.explanation:
The self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made in small-incision cataract surgery (SICS). SICS is a type of extracapsular cataract extraction techniques (ECCE). In these techniques, 
the major portion of the anterior capsule with the epithelium, nucleus, and cortex are removed, 
leaving behind the intact posterior capsule. Note: Newer cataract surgeries include femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS), 
micro-incision cataract surgery (MICS) and Phaconit. FLACS is a microincision cataract surgery or 
a micro-phacoemulsification where a femtosecond laser is used to make the corneal incisions, 
perform capsulorhexis and fragment the lens. MICS refers to the phacoemulsification techniques 
that can be performed through a microincision (<2 mm). Phaconit is the term for the bimanual 
micro-phacoemulsification done with the needle incision technique through an incision of 
<1mm.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 3: In which of the following patients is an intracapsular cataract extraction indicated?
questions.explanation:
At present, the only indication of intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is markedly subluxated 
and dislocated lens. In ICCE, the entire cataractous lens along with the intact capsule is removed by rupturing the 
zonules. Therefore, weak and degenerated zonules are a prerequisite for this method. Methods of 289 
Sold by @itachibot lens delivery include cryoextraction (best method), forceps extraction (Arruga forceps), wire vectis 
method and Indian Smith method. ICCE is no longer used for cataract treatment due to the large 
incision required, inability to implant an IOL and a high rate of complications like vitreous loss, 
retinal detachment and cystoid macular edema.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 4: What is the length of the incision used in phacoemulsification?
questions.explanation:
The length of the incision in phacoemulsification varies from 1.5 to 2.4 mm. The option closest to 
this answer is B, i.e., 2 to 2.5 mm. In phacoemulsification, the nucleus of the lens is emulsified and aspired. This is done by the 
phacoemulsifier. It acts through a hollow 1-mm titanium needle, which vibrates by at an 
ultrasonic speed of 40000 times a second. The steps of phacoemulsification are given below: • Step 1 - Small clear corneal incision • Step 2 - Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis • Step 3 - Hydro dissection • Step 4 - Hydro delineation is done in some cases. • Steps 5 and 6 - Emulsification and aspiration of the nucleus • Step 7 - Removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique • Step 8 - Implantation of a foldable lens Length of the incision in various cataract surgeries: • Phacoemulsification- 1.5–2.4 mm. • Micro-phacoemulsification- 1–1.5 mm. • Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE)- 12–14 mm. • Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE)- 8–12 mm. 290 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common late complication following cataract surgery?
questions.explanation:
The most common late complication following cataract surgery is posterior capsule opacification. Posterior capsule opacification, known as after or secondary cataract, is the most common late 
postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of 
left out anterior epithelial cells.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 6: In a patient undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is the most important 
strategy in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis?

options.b: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.explanation:
The most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis is preoperative 
preparation with povidone-iodine. Postoperative endophthalmitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis. Flora of 
the eyelids and conjunctiva are the most frequent source. Other potential sources include 
contaminated solutions and instruments, environmental air, and the surgeon and other operating 
room personnel. Prophylaxis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes: • Instillation of 5% povidone-iodine into the conjunctival fornices and leaving this undisturbed for 
at least 3 minutes prior to surgery. This is the most important factor. • Scrupulous preparation of the surgical site • Treatment of pre-existing infections such as blepharitis • Antibiotic prophylaxis • Intracameral cefuroxime (1 mg in 0.1 mL) injected into the anterior chamber (AC) at the end of 
surgery. 291 
Sold by @itachibot • Post-operative subconjunctival injection can achieve bactericidal levels in the AC for at least 1–2 
hours. • Preoperative topical fluoroquinolone antibiotics are frequently given in regimens from 1 hour to 
3 days before surgery Patients present with ocular pain, diminished vision, circumciliary congestion and hypopyon. The 
differential diagnosis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes retained lens material in the AC, 
vitreous hemorrhage, postoperative uveitis and toxic reaction to the use of inappropriate or 
contaminated irrigating fluid or viscoelastic.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual 
disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition? 281 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.explanation:
A post cataract surgery patient presenting within 36 hours of surgery with inflammation, 
congestion and hypopyon as seen in the image, is suggestive of acute bacterial endophthalmitis. 
The treatment of acute bacterial endophthalmitis is intravitreal antibiotics. Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the inner structures of the eyeball. 
Acute postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis occurs within 1-7 days after cataract surgery and 
the most important factor to prevent it is preoperative administration of 5% povidone iodine. The 
cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and a decrease in vision. The 
patient classically shows inflammation of the eye, corneal edema and a hypopyon due to the 
pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber. Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with a 
combination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning. The various drugs, routes and surgical 
management used to treat endophthalmitis are as follows: • The mainstay of treatment is intravitreal injections of antibiotics. • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus ceftazidime 2.25mg in 0.1ml. • Second choice:Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus amikacin 0.4mg in 0.1ml. • If there is no improvement, a repeat intravitreal injection should be given after 48 hours • Topical antibiotics are started immediately and used frequently. • Vancomycin (50mg/ml) or cefazolin (50mg/ml) • Amikacin (20mg/ml) or tobramycin • Systemic antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice. • Steroid therapy includes: • Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone (0.4mg in 0.1ml) which is started along with antibiotics. • Topical dexamethasone (0.1%) • Oral steroids such as prednisolone are started after 24 hours of intensive antibiotic therapy. • Supportive therapy includes: • Cycloplegics such as atropine 1% 292 
Sold by @itachibot • Anti-glaucoma drugs such as oral acetazolamide or timolol in patients with raised intraocular 
pressure • Pars plana vitrectomy is done if the patient does not improve with the above therapy in 48-72 
hours or when the visual acuity is reduced to hand movements near the eye Other options: Option A: Steroids are given in endophthalmitis to reduce the inflammation of the tissues. The 
preferred route of administration is either by intravitreal injections, topical concentrations or oral 
route. Intravenous route (option A) of administration of steroids is not used in endophthalmitis. Option B: Systemic administration (intravenous) of antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment 
but are commonly used in practice as an add on.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 8: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are 
shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery, supported with the image of vacoulated clusters 
seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls. It is a type of after cataract. After cataract, or secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, is a late postoperative 
complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It is the most common late 
postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of 
left out anterior epithelial cells. Different types of after cataract include: • Elschnig’s pearls: The subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap 
bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule. • Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between 
layers of the capsule. • Dense membranous after-cataract: It is formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision. • Thin membranous after-cataract: It is thickened posterior capsule. 293 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment of after cataract is by Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule, which works 
on the principle of photodisruption, or surgical posterior capsulotomy. Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome is cystoid macular edema (CME) that develops in post-cataract 
surgery patients. Though it is mostly clinically insignificant, some cases can present with blurring 
of vision, one to three months after surgery. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance 
and on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image 
depicts the flower petal pattern seen on FFA. Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis presents as ocular pain, diminished vision and 
hypopyon within months to years after the surgery. Fungal endophthalmitis can rarely occur with 
puff ball exudates in the vitreous cavity. Option D: UGH syndrome is where uveitis, glaucoma and hyphema occurs simultaneously. It is 
seen commonly with rigid anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 9: What is the treatment of choice for after cataract?
questions.explanation:
Nd:YAG laser is the treatment of choice for after cataract. Thin membranous after-cataract, thickened posterior capsule and Elschnig's pearls are treated 
with Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy. Dense membranous after-cataract requires capsulotomy using a 
vitreous cutter. Sommering's ring, if the central posterior capsule is clear, requires no treatment. Other options: Option A: Intra-capsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is currently used for the treatment of 
markedly subluxated and dislocated lens. Option B: Intravitreal steroids may be used for the treatment of acute endophthalmitis, an early 
postoperative complication of cataract surgery. Option C: Anterior vitrectomy is performed for the treatment of cystoid macular edema with 
vitreous incarceration. This is a late post-cataract surgery complication. 294 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 10: What is the cause of late-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery?
questions.explanation:
Late-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery is caused by Propionibacterium acnes. Late or delayed-onset endophthalmitis following cataract surgery develops when an organism of 
low virulence such as P. acnes, becomes trapped within the capsular bag (saccular 
endophthalmitis). Organisms can become sequestered within macrophages, protected from 
eradication but with continued expression of bacterial antigens. Patients present with symptoms 
between 4 weeks to years (mean 9 months) postoperatively following an uneventful cataract 
surgery.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 11: An elderly male residing in an old-age home is brought to the hospital with senile cataracts in 
both eyes. He says he had difficulty in seeing objects for a few years, but never went to the 
clinic. He is posted for surgery in 3 weeks. Which of the following is a complication is he 
unlikely to develop in the 3 weeks until his surgery?
questions.explanation:
Hypopyon is not a complication of senile cataracts. Hypermature, or senile cataracts, can lead to the following complications. • Phacoanaphylactic uveitis: The lens proteins may leak into the anterior chamber. They may act 
as an antigen and induce antigen–antibody reaction, leading to phacoanaphylactic uveitis. • Lens-induced glaucoma: • Phacomorphic glaucoma: Most common, seen in intumescent cataract. The lens swells and 
causes secondary angle closure glaucoma. • Phacolytic glaucoma: Seen in hypermature cataract. The leaked lens proteins are engulfed by 
macrophages, which clog the trabecular meshwork and cause secondary open-angle glaucoma. • Phacotopic glaucoma: Seen in hypermature cataract. The lens may subluxate or dislocate and 
block the angle of the anterior chamber. • Subluxation or dislocation of the lens: It may occur due to degeneration of zonules in 
the hypermature stage.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 12: What is the best irrigating fluid for cataract surgery? 283 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The best irrigating fluid for cataract surgery is balanced salt solution plus glutathione (BSS plus). In the early days of phacoemulsification, the only irrigating solutions available were normal 
saline, plasmalyte, and lactated Ringer’s solution. Their main adverse effects were endothelial cell 
toxicity. The buffer in BSS Plus is bicarbonate, which is an improvement over the sodium acetate 
and citrate buffers in BSS.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 13: How many weeks following surgery are spectacles prescribed?
questions.explanation:
295 
Sold by @itachibot Spectacles are prescribed 6 weeks after cataract surgery after the course of steroids is over. It is 
the time required for the incison to heal. Then visual acuity is checked and glasses are prescribed.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 14: A 72-year-old diabetic who underwent uncomplicated cataract extraction with PCIOL implant 
15 days back presents with painless, decreased vision in the operated eye. His visual acuity is 
6/12 and does not improve with a pinhole. On examination, the anterior chamber is deep, and 
PCIOL is well-centered in the capsular bag. Dilated fundus exam reveals clear media, and 
optic nerve with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.4, a few peripheral microaneurysms, and a dull foveal 
reflex. The rest of the fundus exam is unremarkable. Which test would be of least benefit?
questions.explanation:
In the above case scenario, gonioscopy would be the least helpful. A painless decrease in vision after cataract surgery could be due to: • Posterior capsular opacification (most commonly, after 1-3 months) • Cystoid macular edema (early) • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (delayed) In the given question, the media is clear (rules out posterior capsular opacification). Also, there 
are no symptoms nor signs of retinal detachment (RD), hence it is ruled out. Decreased vision not 
improving with a pinhole in the presence of clear media is attributable to macular pathology. Also, 
there is a dull foveal reflex. The diagnosis in this patient is cystoid macular edema (CME). The incidence of clinical CME is about 1% to 2% following uncomplicated cataract surgeries. The 
incidence of angiographic evidence of CME is 10 times greater at around 10% to 20%. Optical coherence tomography (option A) is useful in identifying cystoid macular edema and 
evaluating the vitreomacular interface. It is also useful in the measurement of retinal thickening, 
thus allowing the assessment of the therapeutic response. On fluorescein angiography (option B), 
the classic petaloid leakage in the fovea is seen in the case of CME. Amsler’s grid (option D) is a 
macular function test. Hence, the least useful in this scenario is gonioscopy.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 15: Two months after undergoing cataract surgery, a 45-year-old man is found to have after 
cataract. He is planned for an Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy. What is the principle 
behind the use of this laser?
questions.explanation:
The principle of the Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) is photodisruption. Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy is used for treatment of thin membranous after-cataract, posterior 
capsular opacification and Elschnig's pearls. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and 
disrupts the tissues, creating an opening. Double frequency Nd:YAG laser is used in posterior 
segment photocoagulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following complaints in a patient presenting to your OPD would prompt you to 
perform a Fincham's test?
questions.explanation:
Fincham's test is used to distinguish whether the colored halos are due to cataract or glaucoma. Colored halos are rainbow-colored rings seen around lights at nighttime. It may be caused by 
cataracts, acute congestive glaucoma and mucopurulent conjunctivitis. These conditions lead to 
prismatic disruption of light. 296 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 17: As part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked 
to calculate the power of the IOL to be implanted. What investigation do you perform?
questions.explanation:
The power of the intraocular lens (IOL) to be implanted after cataract surgery is calculated by a 
biometer and the procedure is termed as biometry. Biometry consists of keratometry and axial length measurement. The most common method of 
determining IOL power uses a regression formula called modified Sanders–Retzlaff– Kraff (SRK) 
formula, which is given below: E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K Where, • E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye • A is a predetermined constant, which is specific for each intraocular lens type • L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeter, determined by using the "A" scan 
ultrasonography • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry. The image given below shows a biometer.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 18: In the SRK formula for intraocular lens power calculation 'E=A-2.5L-0.9K', the value of L is 
estimated using
questions.explanation:
In the SRK formula, the value of L is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry. The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the modified 
Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff (SRK) formula, given by: E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K Where, • E: Emmetropic power designated for the eye • A: Predetermine constant which is specific for each intraocular lens type. 297 
Sold by @itachibot • L: Axial length of eyeball in millimeters, determined using the A scan ultrasonography. • K: Average corneal curvature determined by keratometry. Given below is an image of A scan ultrasonography.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 19: What is a rigid intraocular lens made of?
questions.explanation:
Rigid IOLs are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA). Depending on the type of material of manufacturing, 3 types of posterior chamber intraocular lens 
(PCIOLs) are available: • Rigid IOLs are made entirely from polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA). • Foldable IOLs are made of silicone, hydrogel, acrylic, and Collamer. These are implanted 
through a small incision. • Rollable IOLs are ultra-thin IOLs made of acyrlic or hydrogel. These are implanted through a 
1-mm incision after micro-incision cataract surgery technique.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient, on follow-up after cataract surgery, has the lens shown below. What is the type of 
lens implanted in the patient?

options.b: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL

questions.explanation:
The image depicts Singh and Worst’s iris claw lens. This lens is an iris-supported lens, which is fixed with the help of sutures, loops or claws. They are 
associated with a high incidence of postoperative complications and are thus only used if posterior 
chamber IOLs cannot be implanted. 298 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is the most commonly 
used ACIOL. Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle 
of the anterior chamber. These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy. 
Thus, they are currently used only for correction of aphakia in cases where posterior chamber 
IOLs cannot be used (eg: rupture of posterior capsule).
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question:
Question 21: An 80-year-old man is posted for cataract surgery. The given lens is chosen to be used for 
implantation. Identify the lens. 286 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
options.c: Singh and Worst's iris claw lens

questions.explanation:
The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL). A PCIOL rests entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed by capsular bag fixation 
of PCIOL (most ideal method), ciliary sulcus fixation or scleral fixation. The PCIOL consists of a central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic and the peripheral 
arms used for placement and stabilization called the haptics. 299 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Question 22: Identify the intraocular lens shown below.

options.a: Depth is less in women than men

questions.explanation:
The given image is of a toric IOL used to correct pre-existing astigmatism. The dotted markings 
on the optic of the IOL indicate the axis of IOL, and it is aligned to coincide with the steep axis of 
the patient’s eye. For every, one degree of misalignment, about 3 percent of the lens cylinder power is lost. 300 
Sold by @itachibot Glaucoma
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery  Complications and IOLs
